stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on creating and implementing platforming assets for Course 11, an oil rig level. Key activities included debugging a major zipline regression, overhauling the game's lighting system for better visuals, and iteratively redesigning the level's color palette based on live feedback. The stream also featured extensive discussion of his game design philosophy and interactions with his wife and collaborator, Zeina.

development_findings.summary: The project is now in the "end game" phase, with the team working on Course 11, an oil rig level inspired by Super Mario Sunshine's Rico Harbor.
Inspired by Mario Odyssey, Kaze re-implemented a camera-based light source to brighten Mario and other moving objects, improving readability and allowing for more dramatic, high-contrast shadows.
development_findings.quote: I added the light coming from the camera back... which makes the whole game look a lot brighter. Because I noticed the game is looking pretty dark.

development_findings.summary: A major regression was discovered where ziplines were broken game-wide. Kaze debugged it live and traced it to a faulty collision optimization he had implemented months ago but never tested.
The retro level within Course 11 will be a recreation of the "Board the Platforms" bonus stage from Super Smash Bros. 64.
development_findings.quote: The retro pipe will be Smash 64 board to platforms.

development_findings.summary: The team changed the primary color of the oil rig's liquid from a reddish-orange to a deep blue/purple after feedback that players were misinterpreting it as lava, altering the level's atmosphere.
Testing on N64 hardware revealed that while performance is high (40-60 FPS), a "clip ratio" optimization is causing severe graphical glitches, described as a "melting" effect.
The planned dojo tutorial level may be scrapped because its function of teaching players new moves has been successfully integrated into the interactions with bunny characters throughout the game.
development_findings.quote: The dojo is now being taught by the bunnies.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans to use a two-week vacation from his day job to potentially implement split-screen multiplayer, considering a week-long, intensive live stream to complete it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes games should provide freedom and avoid hand-holding, such as showing a trajectory for cannons, as it removes player agency and decision-making.
context_findings.quote: I think games should be about experiencing freedom. If I'm giving you the line to move along, you don't have any freedom. You're just kind of following instructions... I'm not a player. I'm like a guy pushing buttons in a factory.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that game design must account for player perception and misinterpretation, even if the designer feels the players are wrong. This was his rationale for changing a level's color scheme that players were misreading.
context_findings.quote: Too many people are stupid. Well, you have to account for that as a designer. People are going to play your game. And if people are stupid, then you have to account for stupid people playing your game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze follows a high-risk, high-reward development philosophy of not testing his code to save time, which sometimes results in bugs that are only discovered months later.
context_findings.quote: See that's the thing with me. I never test my code. I just assume it works. And it saves me a lot of time. And usually it does. And sometimes, months later, a bug just occurs.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has permanently moved his streaming from Twitch to YouTube due to his frustration with Twitch's aggressive and uncontrollable ad system, which he feels creates an unwatchable experience.
context_findings.quote: I find it personally unwatchable with all the ads. Because on YouTube, at least I can decide whether there's ads or not. I can just say I'm not playing an ad and then there won't be an ad.

context_findings.summary: Kaze intentionally inserted factual errors into a recent YouTube video (e.g., incorrect number of improvements, false claims about SM64's history) as a strategy to increase audience engagement through correction comments.

Kaze and Zeina's professional and personal lives are deeply intertwined, as seen in their on-stream banter about their relationship, finances, and household logistics alongside collaborative work on animations and game design.

biobak.summary: Biobak was responsible for the original reddish-orange color of the liquid in the oil rig level, which Kaze described as looking like "running red ash." Kaze also referred to a specific "bio-back pink," suggesting Biobak has a recognizable color palette.

badub.summary: Badub created the custom soundtrack for "Coupa's Revenge 2," which Kaze played on stream. The OST includes remixes of existing Mario songs, which Kaze acknowledges is a copyright gray area.

zeina.summary: Zeina actively participates in the stream from off-camera, preferring to be in the chat but also wanting to be present when she is physically in the room. She and Kaze frequently engage in playful banter.
zeina.quote: I mean, if I'm on stream, it's just weird if I'm in the background and I'm not here. It's just kinda weird.

zeina.summary: Zeina is animating the walk cycle for the Buzzer boss. Kaze provided feedback on a work-in-progress version, and they discussed the intentional lack of head movement so the boss can always face Mario.
Zeina discussed the practical implications of Kaze's idea for a week-long, intensive streaming session to develop multiplayer, highlighting how their work life directly impacts their home life.
zeina.quote: Listen, if you gotta stream all day for a week, at least give me a moment to prepare, so I don't have to cook every day.

key_stories.title: The Zipline Regression
key_stories.summary: Kaze discovered that ziplines were broken game-wide due to an untested optimization he'd made months ago. He debugged the issue live on stream, finding and fixing the simple error in minutes, which served as a perfect example of his "code first, test later" philosophy and its consequences.
key_stories.challenge: A core gameplay mechanic, ziplining, was discovered to be completely non-functional across the entire game, halting progress on the current level's design.
key_stories.process: Kaze first confirmed the bug in a test level, then systematically debugged the code live on stream. He used a crude method of forcing a crash to act as a breakpoint, which allowed him to trace the execution flow and pinpoint the faulty logic in the ceiling detection code.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze identified that the bug was caused by a single misplaced bracket in a collision optimization he wrote months prior. He fixed it within minutes, validating his high-risk development strategy in his own eyes while also demonstrating its potential pitfalls.
key_stories.key_quote: See that's the thing with me. I never test my code. I just assume it works. And it saves me a lot of time. And usually it does. And sometimes, months later, a bug just occurs and it's like, yeah, now I have to prove that I didn't mess up. And I just did.

key_stories.title: The Lighting Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Feeling the game was visually too dark, Kaze took inspiration from Mario Odyssey and re-added a camera-based light to illuminate Mario. This small change had a massive impact, improving character readability and allowing for more dramatic and aesthetically pleasing lighting throughout the game.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze felt the game looked too dark, making it difficult to see Mario against certain backgrounds and lacking visual punch.
key_stories.process: After watching footage of Mario Odyssey, Kaze decided to re-implement a light source that follows the camera, a technique used in the original Super Mario 64. This new light illuminates Mario and other dynamic objects, brightening them independently of the level's static lighting.
key_stories.outcome: The new lighting system dramatically improved the game's visuals, making Mario 'pop' from the background and enabling more artistic, high-contrast lighting with deep shadows. Kaze was extremely pleased with the result.
key_stories.key_quote: Dude, the new lighting is so cool we can add such deep shadows you see that shit? It looks really good.

key_stories.title: The Color of Oil
key_stories.summary: The oil rig level's primary color was causing confusion, with players thinking it was lava. Kaze engaged in a live, iterative redesign process with his community, ultimately switching to a blue/purple palette that better conveyed the intended atmosphere and re-energized his own excitement for the level's art direction.
key_stories.challenge: The liquid in the oil rig level, designed by Biobak to be reddish-orange, was consistently being misinterpreted by viewers as lava or burning ash, which did not fit the intended theme.
key_stories.process: Acknowledging that a designer must account for player perception, Kaze decided to change the color. He experimented live on stream, soliciting feedback from the chat. He tested several colors before landing on a combination of blue and purple that felt more appropriate.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze settled on a deep blue and royal purple palette for the liquid and metal structures. This change resolved the thematic confusion and left him feeling much more excited and satisfied with the level's visual identity.
key_stories.key_quote: This color feels so much more rich to me, you know what I mean? It's like, yeah, this is the color. I want the colors to feel better. Some of the colors in this level just kind of, they don't make me go rock hard.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned he might use a two-week vacation to implement split-screen multiplayer, potentially by streaming non-stop for a week. Zeina commented on the logistical challenges of this, like meal preparation.
questions: What is your design philosophy for adding multiplayer to a traditionally single-player game like Mario 64?
What are the biggest technical and design hurdles you anticipate with split-screen multiplayer?
Zeina, how do you two prepare for and navigate these intense, all-consuming work sprints as a couple working and living together?

open_questions.context: Kaze proudly stated his development philosophy is to write code and assume it works, skipping testing to save time. This directly led to the zipline bug that he fixed on stream.
questions: Can you elaborate on the risk-reward calculation behind your 'never test my code' philosophy?
Has this approach ever led to a bug that was significantly harder to fix or that threatened a major feature?
To the other team members, how does this philosophy impact your work, knowing that a bug in Kaze's code could emerge months later?

open_questions.context: When testing on N64 hardware, the game ran fast but had severe 'melting' graphical glitches. Kaze attributed this to a 'clip ratio' change but was unsure of the exact cause or fix.
questions: Can you explain in layman's terms what the 'clip ratio' is and what performance problem you were trying to solve by changing it?
What is the process for diagnosing a bug that only appears on original hardware?
How does it feel as a creator to see your modern, optimized code produce such bizarre, artistic glitches on the old hardware?

open_questions.context: The original reddish-orange color for the oil rig's liquid was Biobak's idea, but Kaze changed it based on player feedback that it looked like lava.
questions: What was the collaborative process for this change? How do you as a team handle creative feedback when it requires altering another member's work?
Biobak, what was your original intent with the red-orange color, and what are your thoughts on the new blue-purple direction?
Kaze, how do you balance your own vision with community feedback and the creative input of your team?

open_questions.context: The Buzzer boss fight is on hold pending animations from Zeina. She showed a work-in-progress walk cycle and discussed the intentional lack of head movement with Kaze.
questions: Zeina, can you walk us through your animation process for a boss character? What's your workflow from concept to final animation?
How much does the animation design influence the boss's mechanics, and vice-versa?
Can you describe the back-and-forth feedback loop between animator and programmer when creating a boss fight?
